question: What is the probability of finding an electron at a point within an atom?
option1: proportional to the square of the orbital wave function
option2: proportional to the orbital wave function
option3: proportional to the twice of the orbital wave function
option4: proportional to the cube of the orbital wave function
answer: proportional to the square of the orbital wave function
explanation: The probability of finding an electron at a point within an atom is proportional to the square of the orbital wave function i.e., ψ|<sup>2</sup> at that point. |ψ|<sup>2</sup> is known as probability density and is always positive.
